title: Chinese Taipei Olympic boxer Lin will not fight at world championships: official
description: The Paris Games gold medallist had reportedly agreed to gender testing for world event and submitted results, but has received no response.
content:
Olympic boxing gold medallist Lin Yu-ting will not compete at the world championships starting this week, Chinese Taipei’s association said on Tuesday, despite reportedly submitting her gender test results.

Lin and Algerian boxer Imane Khelif were at the centre of a major gender row at the 2024 Paris Olympics, where they won titles in separate weight classes.

World Boxing said last month that women wanting to compete at the championships in Liverpool on September 4-14 would have to undergo mandatory gender testing under its new policy.

The 29-year-old Lin had agreed to undergo the testing, her coach Tseng Tzu-chiang said at the time.

Chinese Taipei’s boxing association said it submitted the results to World Boxing and had not received a response, the semi-official Central News Agency reported late Monday.

“We cannot allow the athlete to travel to the UK without any guarantee,” the association was quoted as saying.

keywords.name: Olympic boxing gold medallist Lin Yu-ting

summary: Olympic boxing gold medallist, Lin Yu-ting, will not compete at the world championships, despite reportedly submitting her gender test results. This comes after World Boxing announced mandatory gender testing for women wanting to compete in the championships. Despite this, Chinese Taipei's boxing association has not received a response from World Boxing.
shortSummary: Olympic boxing champion Lin Yu-ting will not compete in the World Championships due to lack of guarantee regarding her safety.
argos_summary: Olympic boxing champion Lin Yu-ting will not compete at the upcoming world championships in Liverpool after submitting gender test results that have not yet been confirmed by World Boxing. The Chinese Taipei boxing association has withheld her travel to the UK pending a response, citing uncertainty over the testing outcome. The decision follows a broader policy requiring mandatory gender testing for female boxers at the event.
